reviewText:
I'm sure you've already read this in other reviews, but just in case: The only reason there are so many negative reviews is because there were some issues at launch. And people found that a good enough reason to riot.

After playing for only about half an hour, I can already see where this game is most likely going. I can see a bit of meta forming, and each of the dragons clearly has their own playstyle and purpose. I can't say for sure if this game is going to get better or worse over time - but as is, it's worth an hour or so of your time. It's incredibly easy to pick up (you don't even need to know what any of the keys do the first time you jump into a match. You'll be fine.)

I like how your starting dragon is a bit of a heavyweight. Not the bulkiest of the bunch, I assure you, but they have enough HP so that you'll survive a few of the hits you're no doubt going to be taking while you improve. They're enough of a middle-ground so that you can jump into any of the other dragons with enough basic experience under your belt to know what you're doing.

Though I have only played a few games, I'm noticing that I only see about one of a type of dragon per team, which is nice. It's a good indicator that there isn't a clearly broken dragon to play as. Yet.

The airplay is a little frustrating at times and momentum doesn't seem to work exactly as it should (I would love to see an update where it's possible to build up a lot of speed and then ram right into them. With recoil, of course. Right now, the dragons don't really feel like they have weight to them.) but it's a solid starting point.

That seems to be my all-around opinion on this game, actually. It's hit the ground running with a solid start in it's development and I'd love to see where the devs take the game from here. It's definately possible for this to fall flat, but who really knows? Best of luck to you, devs.

People are regularly saying that the game is not translated into english and that the graphical fidelity is poor.

As for graphical fidelity, the models are obviously done by a small team doing the best they can; don't expect AAA graphics.

However, there is a small issue with the animation framerate which makes the game feel much less fluid than it should (animations are running at 30fps but game engine is capped at 60fps) But, this is a minor issue and can be related to either the netcode or the physics implimentation.

It is a small game with limited weaponry, but that makes balanicng much easier (take BF4's 100+ weapons that all need to be balanced and there are still multiple carbines in that game with are absurdly OP) And focuses on skill-based combat, rather than who has the higher damage output.

1) Ability to drop a million mines at the start of the match, blowing up the poor player who spawns in the same location as you (maybe put a delay on using items at the beginning of the match or add 5 second spawn immunity)
2) Only thing with leveling is gaining DNA to unlock the other dragons (there's nothing else to 'buy' or 'upgrade'; maybe add a shop with customization designs)
3) Only FFA and team DM, maybe add more game modes like Co-op missions in taking out ships (like in the trailer) (plus you can't really join in the same game with friends; maybe add a lobby system?)
4) No information on what each dragon's special ability does; I had to play them in order to figure it out (put it in the info box for each dragon on the main page)
5) Spawn camping in FFA (aka dropping 3-8 mines in spots where players spawn or sniping them as they spawn; maybe add a 5 second spawn immunity)

Things I like about the game:
1) Dragons (ofc) :3
2) Different classes of dragons with different strategies of playing them
3) The overheat system, aka the battle system (this actually makes you strategize your attacks)
4) Easy to get into and learn (remember to hit F1 when you're somewhere safe to actually read what keys do what)
5) You can switch between third person and 'first person' by scrolling with mouse wheel (first person is similar to that shown in trailer; other reviews saying there's no first person just didn't know how to scroll imo)

I like the game so far, and I hope that the devs take note of suggestions posted in these reviews :P

PS: Apparently the meta for the game already is dropping mines all over the place; then dropping more mines; and more; and lure enemies into more mines >_> (mines jfc plz nerf rly XD jk don't nerf it's valid strategy just annoying :P )

reviewText:
For a free, early access game this is looking pretty good so far. I enjoy flying around and defeating other dragons with the use of missiles and plasma cannons. I even went through a phase of playing this game often and in doing so, I noticed I was playing with the same players over and over. Even the leaderboards contain mostly players I have seen and played with before. After playing against some of the same people a few times, it can actually feel like two players have something against each other and begin trying to kill each other more than the other players. As with many games, you can hurt players on your team which can lead to you being betrayed (this normally only happens when there are no enemies and your team seems to get bored easily) or accidentally hit. Of course this problem lies within player attitude and not the game itself. I can say though, that the lack of enemies (or teammates for that matter) seems to be down to the game seemingly having no team balancing which results in a lot of unfair matches.

The flight feels quite nice and fluid for the most part but it can be hard to determine the scale and distance of certain objects in the environment. So when you are flying around and you notice you're coming quite close to something large, you usually try to turn sharply or pull up which is difficult sometimes as the dragon seems to want to almost drift and keep moving forward as opposed to just sharply and swiftly pulling up. Most of the time you end up crashing into said object which makes you more vulnerable to attack.

The turret/weapon system is great. It features a number of weapons and items to help you in battle such as plasma turrets (default weapon/fire type), missiles and a special attack that is performed with the R key if I can remember correctly. Most of the special attacks are short range and have what seems to be a spherical radius. In my opinion, the Ogre's (big green, tank-like dragon) special attack is overpowered, since he can stun you and keep you in one spot then use his vast amount of health and firepower to quickly dispose of you.

Anyway, my next point about the turret and weapons system is that the crosshair seems to take a very long time to catch up with where your dragon is looking which can be annoying when you have a clear shot ready but your crosshair is nowhere to be seen. Earlier I mentioned items. These items include stamina refill, weapon cooldown, mines (that float in the air) and a smoke screen (I may have missed something from the list). These also have a cooldown period but can give you an edge in battle and instantly regenerate upon respawning after death. The mines and smoke screen can be good items to use and can make a great combo as you can drop a mine if you're being followed, then drop the smoke screen which will blind your enemy and lead them to fly into the mine. The smoke screen can also hide you when you're on low health and allow you to escape. Your dragon can be given a speed boost (shift key) which takes stamina rather quickly but (if you have it equipped) you can use your stamina refill to give your dragon a second boost.

I did notice that the models and sounds seem to be based off other games/movies...
The Inara - Ikran (Avatar) (Similar sounds too)
The Fury - Toothless (HTTYD/2) (Also similar sounds)
The Vampire (mainly it's head) reminds me of creatures from the old game Altered Beast but may just be a coincidence.
Tiamat is given the same name as the bat queen from Darksiders (perhaps this dragon was given this name instead of the vampire since it would have looked too close to Tiamat). Again, perhaps it's just coincidence or I'm just looking into it too much.

This game is very team based with nice graphics and a great idea behind it. It's a great game for passing the time and having fun and can actually be quite competitive. When you have balanced teams, it can be very enjoyable. If you enjoy team based, dragon flying, weapon firing action then this game is for you. I recommend trying this game and seeing what you think. I may have written a bunch of bad points (which I seem to find it hard not to with most things) but I do really like this game.

I apologise for this painfully long (not as painful as my overuse of certain words) review but thank you for reading - if you didn't die of old age before getting to the end... This is my first review.

reviewText:
This is a game with major potential. Seeing how the devs are still working on it as people are reporting bugs and other things, there's a high chance they're going to exploit that potential.

For now, let's talk about the game in its current state. The graphics are good for now. My PC is pretty low-end but I can still run on the highest settings on the opening screen without dropping frames (however, there is an in-game setting for post effects that makes the game look ugly AND drops your frames immensely, so this setting should be removed or fixed pronto, but just turn it off in the in-game settings for now if you're having problems).

Actual gameplay is very, very...
FUN.
I feel like I could play this game for hours on end without getting bored of it. Time will tell if that feeling will continue, but as of right now, everythings running a smooth course. Graphics, audio, animation... none of that really completely matters if the gameplay isn't fun. And this game's gameplay is straight up, pure, magical fun. I mean the concept itself sounds fun, just think about it! Fire-breathing dragons with missiles and lasers mounted to them? That's awesome! And the fact that it is executed so well in this game makes it all feel incredible.

The only bad things in this game are the bugs and some of the audio. Let's start with that audio. The music in this game is pretty darn cool, but the sound effects are plainly sub-par. They need to be remastered in order for me to feel fully submerged into the game, because otherwise, it feels like there's no reality to this game when those fuzzy, low-qual dragon roars play. Now, the bugs are mostly with the HUD. Sometimes when you're in the options menu, you can't click the accept button. That's one example. There are also collision bugs regarding dragons running into walls even when they haven't even touched the walls. Other things, like certain flight animations, need to be polished and more rounded. But perhaps those animations help with the game's charm. Honestly, I really don't care about charm.

All that matters is that you should give this game a shot. It's got class, fun, and dragons with GUNS on them for crying out loud. It deserves a chance, so try it out, at least for a half hour.

TL;DR:
This game has a couple bugs but it's incredibly fun, so try it!

reviewText:
Ok, this game...8/10

To explain such a high rating, let me just say DRAGONS with FREAKING LAZER GUNS! That puts it pretty high in my sights for a one-play kind of game. Then I kept playing. You can only have 3 dragons in the start, but you can get all of them eventually. They cost 3 each and you get a point every level. This is not a pay-to-win at all, I didn't even see an option to pay. The graphics (highest setting) are a lot better than expected and the controls have the perfect balance of complexity (for detailed shooting and movement) and simplicity (for ease of play.)

The only problem I have for this game was the lack of tons of dragons (which wasn't expected anyways), for there is only 10. All of them are different enough to be interesting to play all of them. Also, there are only 2 game modes and a third to come. Free for all and Team deathmatch. The third is some kind of point control, or defend the location, or attack the blimps, or something like that.

More game modes, dragons, and the leveling actually doing something would be the only things I think could make it better. Game modes such as Capture the flag, or a storyline, or custom enemies spawning in, stuff like that. More content to improve replayability. The Dragons are cool as they are, but there are more kinds that can be made. Speciality ones like ones that can resist certain moves, but have a crappy super move. The leveling is a bit of a touchy subject, in the sense that I realize all the dragons are on the same playing field, and leveling that changes stats would make the game unfair. I like the idea of your level unlocking game modes, or perhaps arena rooms (more and more skilled rooms.)

I really like this game, it's exactly what I wanted in my childhood (and I am sure yours too.) I am glad I found it here. Good job developers!

-Azure

This game is simple, yet very addictive. I After spending only 1 hour in the game so far, I already know I will be spending a lot more time in it as the days go by.

reviewText:
Please note: I do actually plan on fixing and editing this review with playtime and this is more of a first look than a review.

There will be a TL;DR

Now, for what I saw so far.

With a dev team of only 7 people this game is good. It looks like they all put effort into the game, and it's optimized beautifully. That being said, a small team doesn't always make the best games mechanics and graphics wise. When I first started the game I was thrown in a room with a dragon staring me in the face, and a basic UI. To the left is information about your dragon, to the right is the possible dragons you can unlock (with info if you hover over the picture of the dragon), the top (which gives you a barebones settings option, an option to quit, and an option to start the game), and the bottom which is filled with items that you can use in the match

The actual gameplay is solid and the gunplay is easy to get into, however there are only two game modes available as of the time this review is written: TDM or DM. Fairly basic modes whos main goal is to get you to understand the weapons that are mounted on to your dragon... and every other dragon. As far as I can see, there are very little if any diversity in the weapons attached to every dragon. This makes the two game modes a battle of Who can shoot first" situation. To combat this they give you a shield you can use to block incoming attacks
date: but nobody really uses it.\n\nOverall this is what you come to expect from a free game. This is truely free: No cash shop and no DLC. Everything in the game can and has to be acquired in game. So far this is only dragons
recommended:
but hopefully this changes in the future.

Pros:
+ Truely free
+ The flying feels great
+ It's optimized hardcore

Cons:
- The audio sounds royalty free
- No diversity in weapons
- Graphics aren't the best

TL;DR

The game is okay but there's not a lot of content."

reviewText:
I played this game a while back when it was just starting out as a Facebook game, poorly translated and still developing. And even at that point in the beginning, it still had WAY more features in it than this Steam version does. And as I watched it develop, it gained even more features, and became truly interesting, one of my favourite apps.

I haven't played in a while, haven't even hopped back over to Facebook to check if it's still there, but regardless when I saw it was on Steam I downloaded it immediately. Even though I was super confused about the reviews talking about how simple and one-dimensional it is, I had tons of fun before and I am greatly looking forward to seeing what they do on Steam.

So I'm saying this now: don't write this game off as mindless and boring until after they finish bringing in the rest of the features, which I'm sure they will. Right now all you can do is hop on different dragons and go shoot people out of the sky, with almost literally nothing else to change or improve how you do so, but with the full set of features it's a wonderful game with many complexities.

It's no more mindless and repetitive than any other multiplayer online battle arena (MOBA) game out there, and since Call of Duty is now a hugely popular series, I'm going to assume that a fair number of people don't find fighting for supremacy and honing your skills and equipment set to suit your strategy for blasting your enemies out of existence to be boring.

Different dragons, different stats, right? You wanna tank, you go ogre. You wanna zip around like NAH NAH NAH NAH CAN'T TOUCH THIS, you go manta. But the equipment, that could all be upgraded, and the stats further specialized. A point to winning and leveling beyond unlocking more dragons. Making enough gold to buy the coolest stuff, getting skins for different looks (leopard spotted Inara, oooh exotic!)

Visually, if you wanted to improve the cooling system for your guns (so you can shoot continuously for longer without your guns overheating and going into cooldown), there would be actual cooling pipes appearing on your dragon's saddle. Need more defence to take less damage? Armour pieces for various parts of your dragon. In the later stages of development that I was still playing during, stat upgrades had visual effects on the look of your dragon, which was so cool in my opinion.

And it really helped that you could focus on the stats that were important to you. I'm more of a CLICK WILDLY AND HOPE SHOTS HIT WHILE FLYING WILDLY AWAY IF SHOT AT kinda player, so I upgraded my shot accuracy (so the cluster of shots is tighter--at base accuracy, shooting at one space would have multiple shots hitting random areas in a cluster, so unless you were right up in another dragon's face you couldn't guaruntee shots would hit exactly where you aimed them, unless you upgraded your accuracy) and my cooling systems, and left my defense and actual firepower to later.

I like this a lot. It's just the right amount of slightly silly, coupled with good solid game mechanics, interesting level topology and swoopy flying.

it DOES have a slightly cheap feel, but the myriad features and optimizations that would be required to make a game like this run like the new DOOM does would require a huge budget and a large pricetag.  This is very healthy small studio development at its finest.

everything works, there are a pleasing amount of upgrades that i was able to earn in a half hours play session, there are some people on servers and the UI makes most stuff pretty clear.

the actual dragonfighting is fun! it's slower paced than other flight or dogfighting games and theres a large variety of animations in the dragon characters which make it feel very natural and cool to flap and glide around and do popup attacks and dive in for the kill. a full server would be very awesome.

lighting (black dragons get old fast)

but omfg dragons! reccomended!

reviewText:
Time to Leave
OverviewI didn't play this game for very long before coming to my conclusions, and really, you don't have to play the game long at all to know what it's about. Time of Dragons was a pretty fun and clever concept, with dragons carrying turrets on their back and blazing into an all-out war with other dragon species. It seems like a rare breed. However, it's spoiled by one fatal flaw: it's multiplayer PvP only.

The Positives1) Engaging, action-filled combat. It's fun to see stuff explode.

2) The dragons, while kind of blocky and mushy-looking, have cool designs, and they're all unique from each other.

3) The game is free to play, and there's no P2W system of any kind.

The Negatives1) It was fun for five minutes, then started getting boring really fast, mostly because of your lack of options. Do you want to PvP in this way or this way? It's all the same thing: kill the other players and win. There was no variety whatsoever, and the few choices you do have aren't very interesting.

2) I couldn't really get a leg-up in terms of experience since everyone who was playing seemed to be higher and better than me. Again, this made the game boring pretty quickly, because there is no skill scaling. What's the point of fighting if I can't win anything? Not fun. Moving on.

3) The abilities don't seem to do anything. I've hit my special ability several times on enemies and tried like hell to get it to land on them. It doesn't seem to hurt them. Even if it did, they usually managed to kill me before I could tell. I tried the fire blast with Tiamat and vampirism thing that drains health with Vampire, and neither seemed to hurt the enemy. Maybe I just couldn't land it right, but should it really be that hard to land? Especially in a high-action environment where I don't have a lot of time to swoop in and hump the enemy before using my ability?

4) Almost the entire playerbase was Russian for some reason. So I couldn't even chat with people. Even if I could, it's not like I'd have anything to say except Hey
